docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, July; 18. -- Not only is President Wilson determined to force his trust bills to enactment at the present session, but, according to a statement made by Secretary Bryan before the Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday, he is very...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July; 18. -- Not only is President Wilson determined to force his trust bills to enactment at the present session, but, according to a statement made by Secretary Bryan before the Foreign Relations Committee on Wednesday, he is very anxious to obtain the Senate's ratification of about twenty of the so-called Bryan peace treaties.
docs.abstract: statement to Senate Committee on Foreign Relations concerning twenty treaties to be presented for ratification

headline.main: WILSON TO PRESS TREATIES ON SENATE; Bryan Says Twenty Will Soon Be Presented for Ratification.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

headline.main: CHEAPER POSTAL ORDERS.; Rates for Sending Money Abroad to be Cut on Aug. 1.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Although Secretary Bryan told the Committee on Foreign Relations on July 15 that he and the President hoped the twenty peace treaties that had been signed could be ratified at this session, the indications are that he will be...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 25. -- Although Secretary Bryan told the Committee on Foreign Relations on July 15 that he and the President hoped the twenty peace treaties that had been signed could be ratified at this session, the indications are that he will be disappointed.
docs.abstract: Senate will shelve treaty for present session

headline.main: SENATE TO SHELVE PROPOSED TREATIES; Twenty Peace Agreements and Colombian and Nicaraguan Conventions Laid Aside.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: Dr. William H. Guilfoy, Registrar of Records in the Health Department, testified yesterday in the investigation of the Coroners' Office now being conducted by Commissioner of Accounts Leonard M. Wallstein. Dr. Guilfoy accused the Coroners' physicians...
docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. William H. Guilfoy, Registrar of Records in the Health Department, testified yesterday in the investigation of the Coroners' Office now being conducted by Commissioner of Accounts Leonard M. Wallstein. Dr. Guilfoy accused the Coroners' physicians of keeping inaccurate records of deaths reported to the Health Department.

headline.main: DR. GUILFOY ASSAILS CORONERS' METHODS; Their Physicians Keep Inadequate Record of Deaths, Says Health Board Registrar.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- As a result of a long discussion at the regular meeting of the Cabinet yesterday, President Wilson today sent cable messages to the Emperor of Austria-Hungary, the Emperor of Germany, the King of Great Britain, the Emperor of...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- As a result of a long discussion at the regular meeting of the Cabinet yesterday, President Wilson today sent cable messages to the Emperor of Austria-Hungary, the Emperor of Germany, the King of Great Britain, the Emperor of Russia, and the President of France tendering his good offices toward bringing about a settlement of the war in Europe.

headline.main: PRESIDENT OF ARGENTINA DIES; Dr. Roque S. Pena, Supporter of Latin Ideals, Succombs in Buenos Aires. TWICE AN AMBASSADOR His Views on Monroe Doctrine Were Uncomplimentary to American Foreign Policy.

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- With only informal discussion, the Senate this afternoon ratified eighteen of the twenty peace treaties negotiated by Secretary Bryan. The treaties with Panama and the Dominican Republic were held back to ascertain what effect...
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- With only informal discussion, the Senate this afternoon ratified eighteen of the twenty peace treaties negotiated by Secretary Bryan. The treaties with Panama and the Dominican Republic were held back to ascertain what effect they would have on existing treaty relations.

headline.main: RATIFY 18 PEACE TREATIES.; More Time Taken on Those with Panama and San Domingo.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times
